Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Mapping of American Legislatures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The increasing polarization of US politics has drawn a growing amount of attention from scholars, journalists, and the public. Concerns about increasing levels of partisan and ideological conflict have raised important questions about representativeness, accountability, and effectiveness of the American government.

Despite the level of attention, scholarly knowledge of the causes and consequences of polarization is limited. This sketchy understanding is especially true of research on the polarization of elected officials, which has focused almost exclusively on the US Congress. Although much important work has been done on polarization in that context, examination of the history of polarization in the House and Senate provides only a limited perspective on the causes of polarization and its effects.

State legislatures, however, are an almost ideal setting for studying political polarization. States vary not only with respect to opinions and attitudes of their citizens, but also with respect to the electoral and legislative contexts that might contribute to greater or lesser partisan conflict.

Yet such research on state politics has been hampered by two problems to date. First, the data on roll call voting--used in standard measures of polarization--are not generally available. Second, where such data are available, polarization measures are not comparable across states.

The investigators in this project propose a solution to both problems and create ideological measures of individual state legislators that are comparable over time, across states, and with the US Congress. These measures are in turn used to assess the level of polarization within each state legislature. Preliminary findings establish wide variation in the extent of polarization. Some states show very little ideological difference between the two parties, while others are marked by a pronounced ideological divide. The project also demonstrates that polarization has evolved differently over time in different states. While polarization has grown in most state legislatures, it has remained constant or diminished in others.

The intellectual merits of this proposal are twofold. First, existing measures of individual and aggregate ideological preferences will be substantially augmented and linked to district and state demographic and electoral data. Second, this project will support multiple studies applying the new measures to study longstanding political questions. These puzzles include the causes and consequences of polarization, the multiple relationships between citizens and representatives, and the institutional and ideological underpinnings of differing policy choices across the states.

The project makes several contributions. It will yield three publicly accessible datasets ranging over all 50 states: legislative roll call data, which is only available today for 1999-2000; estimates of legislator ideology; and measures of political polarization and ideological conflict. All three data sets have numerous uses for scholars, practitioners, journalists, and the public. Along the way, the project will advance the professionalization of graduate students who participate in the research projects. Finally, policymakers and journalists would acquire additional insight into the relationship between institutional reform and ideological conflict.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The increasing polarization of American politics has drawn an increasing amount of attention from scholars, journalists, and the public.  Concerns about increasing levels of partisan and ideological conflict have raised important questions about representativeness, accountability, and effectiveness of the American government.

Yet despite the level of attention, scholarly knowledge of the causes and consequences of polarization is limited.  This sketchy understanding is especially true of research on the polarization of elected officials which has focused almost exclusively on the U.S. Congress.   Although much important work has been done on polarization in that context, the examination of the history of polarization in the House and Senate provides only a limited perspective on the causes of polarization and its effects.

State legislatures, however, are an almost ideal setting for studying polarization.  States not only vary with respect to public opinion, but also with respect to the electoral and legislative contexts which might contributor to greater or lesser partisan conflict. Such research on state politics, however, has been hampered by two problems.   First, the data on roll call voting--used in standard measures of polarization--are not generally available.  Second, where such data is available, polarization measures are not comparable across states. This is because what bills actually get a vote—the legislative agenda—vary dramatically. This makes naïve comparisons of votes problematic.

In this project, we implemented a solution to both problems to create ideological measures of individual state legislators that are comparable over time, across states, and with the U.S. Congress. These measures are in turn used to assess the level of polarization within each state legislature. Our findings clearly establish wide variation in the extent of polarization. Some states such as Rhode Island and Louisiana show very little ideological difference between the two parties, while California and Colorado are marked by a huge ideological divide.  The project also demonstrates that polarization has evolved differently over time in different states.  That variation is tantalizing for academics and outsiders, because it invites analysis to determine its causes and consequences.

The grant has allowed us to create individual and state level measures of state legislative ideology and polarization for over 20,000 legislators for all 50 states from 1993 to 2015. This is a massive extension of the data available at the start of the NSF grant period. Next, extensive software rearchitecting has created a modern revision control system to aid current and future acquisition of roll call data. Third, we have extensively cleaned the data from errors caused by OCR.

All of these innovations have been very successful. First, our raw data has been downloaded over 12,000 times. Next, the broader public interest has been served with data-based blog posts that have been accessed over 150,000 times, with numerous media stories as well. The paper the data is based on has been cited over 340 times. Finally, the investigators themselves have published numerous scholarly works.

Two examples will illuminate the worth of the project in terms of both intellectual merit and broader impact. Reformers – inside and outside government – have almost uniformly implicated the American primary system in the contributing polarization. Their thinking goes as follows: if only primaries were opened up to the broader public, candidates would not have to be beholden to a small minority of party activists that reliably turn out to vote in primary elections. Using our data, I have been involved in three scholarly papers that directly address this question. The finding has been remarkably uniform: there is very little evidence that more open primary systems consistently lead to less polarized legislators. This finding should encourage reformers to look elsewhere in engineering moderating electoral changes.

Another reform that reformers have pushed is redistricting reform, with the idea that more competitive districts would be less likely to elect extremists. With coauthors, I have used the data—connected to new public opinion measures--to show that this is often not true. Competitive districts composed of distinct partisan subgroups often elect extremists, because candidates have incentives to get the base out rather than push for the middle of the district. Here, too, reformers should take note that simplistic redistricting reform might very well have powerful unintended consequences.

Along the way, the project has advance the professionalization of graduate students who participate in the research with the PIs. In fact, several graduate students have gone on to tenure-track faculty careers.

All in all, the project has served to significantly advance the scholarly discussion of polarization and its causes and consequences. At the same time, the project has served broader societal goals, especially in its impact in the area of electoral engineering to ameliorate polarization. Finally, the project is in a place such that future contributions from ourselves and others are possible, and we have continued to work on it in the post-grant period.
